resources.string: A craft beer bar that gets everything right.
Small, secretive and playful but always serious about the cocktails.
This long-standing Soho spot is old-school and unpretentious, with a heritage as a writers\’ drinking den.
A cozy and unassuming little boozer bringing a touch of flamenco to Fitzrovia.
Think Bugsy Malone for grown-ups and you\’re about there.
Find eye-opening dusky glamour any time of the day at this hideaway of supreme style.
Built in 1984, Tower Bridge is the most iconic bridge in London.
The historic site has been a palace, prison, armoury and powerful fortress.
Discover the Hampton Court Palace, Henry VIII\'s favourite royal residence.
Explore the rooms Queen Victoria used as a child.
Kenwood House is a magnificent stately home in Hampstead.
Built in 1535 by Henry VIII\'s Secretary of State, Sir Ralph Sadleir.
A chance to see world famous art and get inside HRH\’s HQ.
The London Eye first started turning in 2000 and remains the world\’s tallest cantilevered observation wheel.
The View from The Shard is one of the city\’s very best vantage points.
Informal but slick service and a big-ticket menu from Ramsay protégé and unstoppable wunderkind Jason Atherton.
A dinky Soho eatery serving fiery food you can eat with your fingers – and have time to queue.
A Latin dance party on your plate and in your glass!
A restaurant serving exclusively Sri Lankan dishes in the heart of Soho.
Thai street food in a stylish and exotic former garment factory walking distance from Liverpool Street.
A ‘modern Israeli\’ small plates restaurant in the heart of Neal\’s Yard, Covent Garden.
